The first time that Pierre Grassou had seen the Vervelle family was in his studio, when they came to have their portraits painted. The father, a retired merchant, was a stout man with a cocoa-nut shaped body, and a wife with a veneer of mahogany on her face. Their daughter, Virginie, was a young woman with a tiny head, stringy arms, and a large innocent look in her eyes.
